messages.message:
Invoking: `validate` with `{'patch': '--- a/ext/standard/scanf.c\n+++ b/ext/standard/scanf.c\n@@ -506,7 +506,13 @@\n                 }\n             }\n-            nassign[objIndex]++;\n+            if (objIndex < nspace) {\n+                nassign[objIndex]++;\n+            } else {\n+                zend_value_error("Format string references variable index %d, which is out of bounds (max %d)", objIndex + 1, nspace);\n+                goto error;\n+            }\n             objIndex++;\n         }\n     } /* while (*format != \'\\0\') */\n'}`
responded: The root cause of the vulnerability is that `nassign[objIndex]++` at line 508 in `ValidateFormat` can access out-of-bounds memory if `objIndex >= nspace`. The code tries to expand the `nassign` buffer if this is the case, but there are code paths where `objIndex` can still be out of bounds, especially if the format string is malformed or manipulated.

**Key observations:**
- The code attempts to grow `nassign` if `objIndex >= nspace`, but this logic is only executed if `!(flags & SCAN_SUPPRESS)`.
- If `flags & SCAN_SUPPRESS` is set, the code skips the buffer expansion, but still increments `objIndex` and may access `nassign[objIndex]`.
- There is no check after the switch/case for `objIndex < nspace` before `nassign[objIndex]++`.

**Patch plan:**
- Add a bounds check for `objIndex < nspace` before incrementing `nassign[objIndex]`.
- If the bounds are exceeded, trigger an error and exit gracefully.
